metadata.subject: Jam et al. v. International Finance Corporation

organizations: U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Accountability

relationships.description: IFC provided $450 million loan to finance construction of coal-fired power plant
Plaintiffs sued IFC for damages and injunctive relief over environmental harm
Court ruled on immunity status of international organizations

transactions: Loan agreement for power plant construction

analysis.purpose: To determine whether international organizations have absolute or restrictive immunity from suit
analysis.significance: Landmark decision redefining immunity standards for international organizations under U.S. law

notable_quotes: The IOIA affords international organizations the same immunity from suit that foreign governments enjoy today under the FSIA.
The IOIA's reference to the immunity enjoyed by foreign governments is to an external body of potentially evolving law, not to a specific provision of another statute.

The privileges and immunities accorded by the IOIA are only default rules. If the work of a given international organization would be impaired by restrictive immunity, the organization's charter can always specify a different level of immunity.

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found in this legal opinion

illegal_activity.description: Document is a Supreme Court opinion discussing legal immunity, not containing evidence of illegal activity

public_knowledge.context: Supreme Court decisions are public documents and this ruling on international organization immunity would be of significant interest to legal communities and international organizations

analysis.summary: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled that international organizations like the IFC are entitled to the same restrictive immunity from suit that foreign governments enjoy today under the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act, rather than the absolute immunity they enjoyed in 1945 when the International Organizations Immunities Act was passed.
